snippet: Shell companies are used to shield the identities of buyers in the competition to secure condos at the Time Warner Center and other high-end buildings. This is the first installment in a five-part series.
abstract: Investigation by The New York Times has found that majority of owners of condominiums in Time Warner Center have taken pains to keep their identities hidden by purchasing properties through shell companies; purchases have been enabled by American laws that allow wealthy, including foreigners, to move largely untraceable money through such companies, and they have transformed New York City's real estate market (Series: Towers of Secrecy).

byline.original: By LOUISE STORY and STEPHANIE SAUL
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Xu Wang from New York; Carlotta Gall and Youssef Gaigi from Tunis; Alejandra Xanic von Bertrab from Mexico City; Joe Cochrane from Jakarta, Indonesia; Niki Kitsantonis from Athens; Andrew Roth from Moscow; and Vinod Sreeharsha from Rio de Janeiro. Lisa Schwartz, Neha Thirani Bagri and Amy Qin contributed research.

lead_paragraph: Shell companies are used to shield the identities of buyers in the competition to secure condos at the Time Warner Center and other high-end buildings. This is the first installment in a five-part series.

headline.main: Stream of Foreign Wealth Flows to Elite New York Real Estate
headline.print_headline: Hidden Wealth Flows to Elite New York Condos
